NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government and its agencies ends on 31 
December. FY before a calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal 
year ends, e.g. FY 2004 ends on 31 December 2004. 
 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Lewis.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Agriculture is an important sector in the economy of Viet Nam. Agricultural production 
accounts for 25% of gross domestic product and nearly 30% of exports. Of Viet Nam’s total 
population, approximately 80% lives in rural areas. In addition, the agriculture sector hosts 
about 75% of the workforce. Over the past decade, the agriculture sector has grown by 4–5% 
annually, and this has contributed to poverty reduction. From a food importing country in late 
1980s, Viet Nam has become the world’s third largest rice exporter. The agriculture sector also 
experienced significant production diversification. Managing risks associated with the agriculture 
sector, including production risk and market risk, is an important element in the Government’s 
overall strategy to develop the sector and improve the welfare and livelihood of the rural 
population.  
 
2.   The Government recognizes the importance of agricultural insurance and its potential 
impact on income stabilization and ultimately poverty reduction. However, previous attempts to 
introduce agricultural insurance products were not successful. The constraints and impediments 
to the provision of agricultural insurance need to be carefully examined. Policy options and 
support from the Government should also be considered, bearing in mind the experiences of 
other countries and the Government’s current fiscal constraints. The Government has given 
agricultural insurance a high priority, in the wake of avian flu in 2004. Given the Government’s 
limited experience with agricultural insurance, the Government requested Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA). In response to this request, a concept paper was 
developed and endorsed for funding in the amount of $600,000 by the Poverty Reduction 
Cooperation Fund in July 2004. An ADB fact-finding mission1 visited Hanoi from 4–9 October 
2004  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government on the goals, purpose, scope, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the 
proposed TA.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The primary activity of most rural households is agriculture. The risks faced by farmers 
are many, including weather-related shocks; volatile commodity prices; financial shocks, such 
as  devaluation;  and  negative  policy  changes.  Developed  countries  have  a  variety  of 
government-supported  agriculture-related  insurance  services.  In  contrast,  in  developing 
countries, including Viet Nam, rural residents generally rely on informal arrangements to help 
reduce risks. Such arrangements do not pool risks as efficiently as formal arrangements. The 
lack of efficient risk-mitigation mechanisms exposes farmers to the possibility of incidents where 
loss of income is substantial. Farmers in Viet Nam, as well as those in other developing 
countries, need financially sustainable mechanisms to help them mitigate risks. Insurance is one 
of those mechanisms. 
 
4.  Developing agricultural insurance will have a direct impact on rural residents. From past 
experiences, agricultural insurance fared poorly, at least in part because of problems related to 
moral hazard and adverse selection resulting from asymmetric information. To control adverse 
selection and moral hazard requires better information, and information gathering is costly. 
Recently, to overcome these problems, innovations in agricultural insurance have emerged.

Weather-related index insurance products are a few examples.3 These products offer new

5.   In 2003, the Government approved a strategy for the development of the insurance 
market. The Government also supervises and monitors the insurance business in accordance 
with the laws of Viet Nam and some international standards and practices. Since 1993, Viet 
Nam’s insurance sector has opened and undergone rapid growth and development. Prior to 
1993, only one insurance enterprise operated in Viet Nam, under a subsidy scheme. Four state-
owned enterprises, 4 joint stock companies, 7 joint venture companies, 5 wholly foreign-owned 
enterprises, and 30 representative offices of foreign insurance entities now operate. Behind 
policies to open the market, the insurance sector has realized robust growth. Total revenues 
from premiums of the entire market increased 29% per annum, on average, over the 1998–2003 
period. Furthermore, the number of insurance products increased, which has helped businesses 
and residents become more familiar with the concept of insurance. 
 
6.  Basic insurance business legislation was developed and promulgated. The National 
Assembly approved the Law on Insurance Business in 2000, and the implementing decrees and 
circulars were issued in 2001. The supervision, currently under the Insurance Department of the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), is conducted based on objective financial and economic criteria, with 
a focus on the solvency of insurance enterprises and safeguarding the legitimate rights and 
benefits of insurance buyers. However, most insurance products available are for life and 
property insurance. In the insurance market, the Viet Nam Insurance Corporation (BAOVIET), a 
state-owned insurance company, is the market leader, with revenue reaching more than $268 
million in 2003. BAOVIET has 64 branches operating in all provinces of Viet Nam.  
 
7.  In  1993,  BAOVIET  started  to  offer  rice  crop  insurance  policies  to  farmers  in  12 
provinces. However, from 1993 to 1998, the aggregate loss ratio, defined as indemnity paid to 
farmers divided by total premiums received, was 110.00%, with significant fluctuations from 
province to province. Moreover, the actual area insured in this pilot project, compared to the 
total area of rice planted in the country, was only 1.16% in 1995 and 0.27% in 1997. The pilot 
project apparently was not successful, due to inadequate participation of farmers, resulting in 
low  premiums  received,  difficulty  in  risk  management,  and  inadequate  support  from  the 
Government, including that related to the policy and regulation-enabling environment. BAOVIET 
now has a minor operation providing agricultural insurance. 
 
8.  Recently, as an initiative from a private firm, Viet Nam Groupama Insurance (VGI), a 
French insurance company, has started to offer livestock  insurance in 11 provinces in the 
southern part of Viet Nam. VGI is a wholly owned subsidiary of Groupama France, a company 
specializing in agricultural insurance. In 2001, VGI was granted an operating license to provide 
insurance to crop, livestock, and aquatic farmers. Its operation is mainly carried out in the 
Mekong Delta. The company faced difficulties in the initial period of operation, given the low 
participation rate, great moral hazard, high claim ratio, and lack of information infrastructure. 
 
9.  Sustainable agricultural insurance in Viet Nam offers the potential for reducing the 
vulnerability of poor farmers in rural areas. Given the Government’s strong support of the 
insurance  sector  and  the  insurance  sector’s  enabling  environment,  assistance  to  develop 
agricultural insurance is needed.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The  purpose  of  the  TA  is  to  (i)  identify  impediments  to  developing  sustainable 
agricultural insurance in Viet Nam and propose policy options, (ii) provide feasible models for 
informal agricultural risk mitigation and formal agricultural insurance for pilot testing, and (iii) 
conduct pilot testing of informal and formal risk mitigation models. The results of the TA will 
have  potential  implications  on  the  design  of  the  agricultural  insurance  program  and  will 
contribute to the Government’s strategy to develop agricultural insurance in Viet Nam. Appendix 
1 gives the TA framework, and Appendix 2 contains the summary initial poverty and social 
analysis. 
 
11.  The TA will have two phases. The first phase is an in-depth study and survey, which will 
cover 8 months. A comparative study of informal and formal risk management systems will be 
conducted.  The  consulting  team  will  review  and  assess  experiences  in  other  countries, 
particularly less-developed countries, related to agricultural insurance. Weather-related index 
insurance will be especially investigated. 
 
12.  Furthermore, a study of the specific needs for agricultural insurance products in Viet 
Nam will be conducted to assess whether there exists sufficient demand for these products. The 
study will determine the major risks that farmers face, establish how farmers are currently 
coping with risks, and ascertain products that might be useful for them. Information on informal 
risk coping mechanisms, including farm and livestock management, and the importance of 
savings and credit to manage risks will be obtained. In addition, affordability and willingness to 
pay of poor farmers will be assessed. This study will be done through a survey, with appropriate 
sampling  methods  and  questionnaires,  and  results  will  be  rigorously  analyzed. 
Recommendations  for  agriculture-related  risk  prevention  will  be  stratified  according  to  the 
beneficiaries’ income level. The findings will be useful for designing appropriate insurance 
products that reduce the vulnerability of poor farmers.  
 
13.  The  TA  will  identify  impediments  to  sustainable  agricultural  insurance  in  Viet  Nam, 
including legal framework, institutional capacity, and informational infrastructure, and propose 
policy  options  for  providing  financially  viable  agricultural  insurance.  With  respect  to  crop 
insurance, a feasibility study of a weather-related index insurance product will be conducted, 
with assessment of formal regulations, informational infrastructure, detailed product design, and 
proposed  reinsurance.  Recommendations  from  the  TA  will  adhere  to  the  principles  of 
commercial insurance. In addition, the issue of whether a government subsidy is justified will be 
analyzed. The TA will also support capacity building in MOF’s Department of Insurance. A pilot 
project for weather-related index insurance will be designed, based on the results of the survey 
and other studies being done in the first phase. With respect to livestock insurance, the most 
feasible way of insuring livestock will be investigated. To mitigate risks with regard to livestock, 
another pilot project for informal risk coping mechanisms will be designed. Before the end of the 
first phase, ADB interdepartmental and Department for International Development reviews will 
be conducted, to determine whether a case can be made for undertaking a pilot project. 
 
14.  The second phase is for pilot testing, which will cover 18 months. Two pilot projects are 
expected. The first pilot project will test the appropriateness of the weather-related index 
insurance product for crop insurance or any suitable alternative proposed in the first phase. The 
second pilot project will test a selected informal risk coping mechanism of the poor with regard 
to livestock. The training to raise awareness of participants on the concept of insurance and the

4  
appropriate ways to manage their crops or the health of livestock will be one component of the 
pilot  project.  Results  from  the  pilot  projects  will  be  rigorously  analyzed,  to  evaluate  the 
effectiveness of the pilot schemes, and recommendations will be proposed to the Government. 
Lessons learned and evaluation results will also be disseminated to stakeholders. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The TA will fund consultants with expertise in agricultural insurance and microinsurance. 
A team of consultants will be recruited to work with counterpart staff members to accomplish 
required  deliverable  outputs.  Major  activities  will  include  reviewing  the  existing  market 
conditions of agricultural insurance in Viet Nam and pursuing in-depth consultations with public 
and private stakeholders to ensure that the proposed policy options are practical within the 
Vietnamese economic and operational environment. Consultations with the private sector to 
assess the level of interest and major constraints and suggestions for improving regulatory 
framework  are  also  crucial.  Discussions  and  workshops  with  policy  makers,  government 
officials, and other stakeholders will be held during TA implementation, to gather opinions, 
disseminate information, and build consensus on the optimal approach for fostering agricultural 
insurance in Viet Nam. The proposed TA will also fund study tours for officials involved in the 
implementation of the agricultural insurance program in Viet Nam, and these tours are expected 
to occur in the second phase. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost a total of $750,000 equivalent, including a foreign exchange 
cost  of  $335,500  and  a  local  currency  cost  of  $414,500  equivalent.  A  total  of  $600,000 
equivalent, including the entire foreign exchange cost and $264,500 equivalent of the local 
currency cost will be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund, to 
be administered by ADB. From the grant of $600,000, the amount of $120,000 is allocated for 
the pilot projects, and the amount of $10,000 is allocated for study tours, which are activities 
expected to occur in the second phase of the TA, provided that the approval to continue to the 
second phase is granted. The Government will contribute $150,000 equivalent in-kind for office 
space,  counterpart  staff  members,  and  other  miscellaneous  services.  Details  of  the  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  MOF will be the Executing Agency and responsible for the overall implementation of the 
TA. In addition to office space, MOF will provide counterpart staff members and other support 
services to the consultants. A TA steering committee, which comprises representatives of 
BAOVIET,  MOF,  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam,  Viet  Nam  Bank  for  Agriculture  and  Rural 
Development and Viet Nam Farmers Union, will oversee TA implementation. MOF will appoint a 
project officer for the purpose of assisting in daily TA implementation. During the TA inception 
meeting, ADB’s anticorruption policy will be explained.4 
 
                                                 
4 Attention will be drawn to the section on fraud and corruption that was added to ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement 
and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, particularly the need for bidders, suppliers, contractors, and consultants 
to observe the highest standards of ethics in procuring and executing ADB-financed contracts, and the sanctions if 
fraud and corruption are discovered.

5
18.  The TA will require 10 person-months of international and 14 person-months of domestic 
consultant inputs. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. The TA will be 
contracted to an international consulting firm. The contract with the consultants will be based on 
quality- and cost-based selection. Short-listed firms will submit simplified technical proposals. 
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the  Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. All procurement under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
19.  In the second phase of the TA, one or two study tours will be organized by the 
consultants  to  build  the  capacity  of  the  officials  concerned  in  the  implementation  of  the 
agricultural  insurance  program  in  Viet  Nam.  The  countries  for  study  tours  and  visits  to 
institutions will be carefully selected, considering their relevance to Viet Nam. The consultant 
team will be responsible for making all necessary arrangements for the study tours. The 
participants will be required to submit to the consultant team and ADB reports of the study tours 
no later than 3 weeks after their return, citing the relevance of the study tours to their work. 
 
20.  The consultants will prepare detailed work plans (including a timetable for deliverables 
defined under the TA, in consultation with MOF) before the start of the services. The consulting 
firm is required to submit an inception report 2 weeks after commencing the Project. An interim 
report will be submitted 8 weeks after the submission of the inception report and will be 
reviewed by MOF and ADB. A draft final report will be submitted within the deadline specified in 
the work plan, after incorporating feedback from MOF and ADB. A tripartite meeting will be held 
before finalizing the draft final report. The final report, incorporating comments of MOF and ADB 
during and after the tripartite meeting, will be submitted upon completion of service in the first 
phase. If a decision is made to continue the pilot testing in the second phase, both international 
consultants  will  continue  to  provide  services  on  an  intermittent  basis  for  the  effective 
implementation of the pilot projects. An evaluation report summarizing the results of the pilot 
projects and recommendations will be submitted 1 month after completion of the pilot testing. 
The TA is expected to be implemented over a period of 26 months, from April 2005 to May 
2007. 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for the 
purpose of Developing Agricultural Insurance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
The development of the agricultural insurance subsector contributes to poverty reduction in Viet Nam. Farmers face 
numerous risks in agricultural production, and they use several mechanisms to cope with risks. Informal risk 
mitigating mechanisms of farmers will be investigated, and recommendations for replicating these mechanisms will 
be suggested. For formal agricultural insurance in Viet Nam, previous efforts to provide agricultural insurance 
services were unsuccessful. However, the Government recognized the importance of agricultural insurance and its 
potential effect on poverty reduction. The results from this technical assistance will contribute to the Government’s 
overall strategy in insurance sector development and the design of an agricultural insurance program in Viet Nam.  
 
 B.  Poverty Analysis  Targeting Classification: General intervention  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The technical assistance aims at reducing vulnerability and poverty of low-income people in the agriculture sector 
facing production risk. Therefore, the assistance has a direct implication for poverty reduction. The successful 
implementation of agricultural insurance products will help farmers manage risks and stabilize their incomes. Risk 
coping mechanisms by self-help groups, if successfully replicated in larger areas, will contribute to risk reduction 
and income stabilization of farmers. Ultimately, these innovations in formal insurance and microinsurance are 
expected to reduce vulnerability and poverty of farmers.
